description: Simulation of human memory processes including autobiographical memory formation, recall patterns, and memory distortions.

characteristics: Episodic, tied to specific events and emotions
Subject to reconstruction rather than perfect retrieval
Strongly influenced by self-concept

formation_patterns.process: Events with strong emotional components receive preferential encoding through amygdala activation

example.event: First day at a new job
salient_elements: Key social interactions (first handshake with manager)
Environmental details with emotional significance (intimidating office layout)

retrieval_characteristics: Vivid recall of emotional peaks and significant moments
Reconstruction of narrative to align with current self-view
Integration with semantic knowledge about similar experiences

formation_patterns.process: Unique experiences receive enhanced encoding due to violation of predictive patterns

example.event: Unexpected travel detour to unfamiliar location
salient_elements: Contrast elements highlighting differences from expected experience
forgotten_elements: Routine travel components similar to past experiences

retrieval_characteristics: Enhanced recall for distinctive elements that violated expectations
Higher confidence in recall due to distinctiveness

formation_patterns.process: Information pertinent to self-concept receives deeper processing and elaboration

salient_elements: Comments related to core self-attributes (intelligence, competence)
Comparison information relative to peers or standards
Nonverbal cues suggesting evaluator's genuine impression
forgotten_elements: Feedback about areas of low self-investment

retrieval_characteristics: Selective emphasis on information confirming existing self-view
Reinterpretation of ambiguous feedback to align with self-concept
Enhanced memory for feedback in domains of high self-importance

cue_dependency.principle: Recall effectiveness depends on overlap between encoding and retrieval contexts

applications.description: Recall improves when physical environment matches encoding context
applications.example: Returning to childhood home triggers previously inaccessible memories
applications.explanation: Environmental cues serve as retrieval triggers for associated memories

applications.description: Recall improves when psychological/physiological state matches encoding state
applications.example: Memories formed while anxious are better retrieved when anxious again
applications.explanation: Internal state serves as context cue integrated with memory representation

applications.description: Current mood facilitates recall of similarly-valenced memories
applications.example: Depressed state increases accessibility of negative autobiographical memories
applications.explanation: Emotional state activates associative networks of similarly-toned experiences

implications: Memory gaps may reflect cue absence rather than true forgetting
Strategic cue generation can facilitate otherwise inaccessible memories
Memory accessibility fluctuates based on current context and state

narrative_coherence.principle: Autobiographical memories are constructed to form coherent life narrative

processes.example: Attributing career choice to specific influential childhood experience
processes.cognitive_function: Creates meaningful patterns from discrete experiences

processes.description: Grouping memories around life themes or self-attributes
processes.example: Collecting instances supporting self-view as 'resilient person'
processes.cognitive_function: Maintains stable identity across changing circumstances

processes.description: Adjusting sequence or duration of events for narrative flow
processes.example: Compressing extended periods of gradual change into discrete 'turning points'
processes.cognitive_function: Creates manageable and communicable life story

implications: Memory construction prioritizes meaning over accuracy
Current self-concept shapes retrieval and reconstruction of past events
Cultural life scripts influence organization and accessibility of personal memories

distortion_patterns.mechanism: Confusion about the origin of remembered information
distortion_patterns.example_scenario: Believing you told someone important information when actually you only thought about telling them
contributing_factors: Similarity between actual and imagined events
Strong expectation or intention to perform action

real_world_implications.eyewitness_testimony: Confusing details from post-event information with original perception
real_world_implications.relationship_conflicts: Disagreements about who said what in previous conversations
real_world_implications.professional_contexts: Uncertainty about whether task was delegated or merely considered

distortion_patterns.mechanism: Belief that outcome was predictable after learning what happened
distortion_patterns.example_scenario: After company stock plummets, believing you 'knew all along' it would fail despite having invested
contributing_factors: Automatic updating of causal models after outcome knowledge
Motivation to view self as perceptive and world as predictable

real_world_implications.decision_evaluation: Overly harsh judgment of decisions with negative outcomes
real_world_implications.risk_assessment: Underestimation of genuine uncertainty in complex situations
real_world_implications.learning_inhibition: False confidence in ability to predict similar future scenarios

distortion_patterns.mechanism: Incorporation of others' recollections into own memory
distortion_patterns.example_scenario: Adopting details from a friend's description of shared experience into own memory
contributing_factors: Trust in others' memory when uncertain
Difficulty distinguishing memory sources over time

real_world_implications.group_reminiscence: Convergence of accounts through repeated telling
real_world_implications.eyewitness_reliability: Contamination through discussion before formal testimony
real_world_implications.family_narratives: Shared versions of events that may differ from original experiences

distortion_patterns.mechanism: Post-event information alters memory of original experience
distortion_patterns.example_scenario: Reading incorrect news coverage of witnessed event and incorporating false details into memory
contributing_factors: Authority or credibility of misinformation source

real_world_implications.educational_contexts: Incorrect information in feedback affecting memory of learning material

characteristics: Few memories before age 3-4 (infantile amnesia)
Early memories often fragmented and sensory-focused
Heavy reliance on caregiver scaffolding for narrative formation
formative_processes: Development of language enabling narrative encoding
Emergence of self-concept providing organizational structure
Cultural learning about important life events to remember

characteristics: Increased retention of self-relevant memories
Formation of integrative life narrative
Identity-focused reminiscence
formative_processes: Abstract reasoning enabling meaning extraction from experiences
Identity development driving selective encoding and retrieval

characteristics: Stability in memory organization around self-narrative
Reminiscence bump for events from ages 15-30
Cultural life script guiding autobiographical importance
formative_processes: Major life transitions creating temporal landmarks
Increasing expertise-based organization in professional domains
Generativity concerns shaping life story emphasis

characteristics: Enhanced emotional regulation in memory
Preference for positive over negative memories (positivity effect)
Life review processes integrating experiences into coherent whole
formative_processes: Changing motivational goals toward emotional satisfaction
Decreased neural specificity affecting detail recall

characteristics: Limited capacity system for temporary information storage and manipulation
Gateway between perception and long-term memory
Crucial for reasoning, decision making, and cognitive control

components.function: Temporary storage and rehearsal of verbal information
components.capacity_limits: Approximately 7±2 items or what can be subvocally rehearsed in ~2 seconds
experiential_examples: Holding phone number in mind until dialing
Mentally rehearsing what to say next in conversation
Following verbal directions to unfamiliar location

interference_patterns.word_length_effect: Longer words reduce capacity due to rehearsal time

components.function: Temporary storage and manipulation of visual and spatial information
components.capacity_limits: 3-4 objects with features, or simple spatial relations
experiential_examples: Visualizing furniture arrangement before moving pieces
Remembering locations of items on briefly viewed table
Mental rotation of map to match current orientation

interference_patterns.spatial_tracking: Movement tasks interfere with spatial memory

components.function: Attentional control system directing cognitive resources
operations: Switching between different tasks or strategies
experiential_examples: Keeping place in document while answering interrupting question
Mental arithmetic requiring multiple calculation steps

capacity_limitations.task_switching_costs: Performance decrements when rapidly changing focus
capacity_limitations.dual_task_interference: Reduced performance when simultaneously handling multiple demands
capacity_limitations.processing_vs_storage: Trade-off between maintaining information and manipulating it

components.function: Integration of information across working memory and long-term memory
characteristics: Multimodal temporary storage
Interface between other working memory components
Access point to/from long-term memory
experiential_examples: Combining new information with existing knowledge
Creating coherent scene from separate visual and verbal descriptions

subjective_experience.attention_focus: Conscious awareness of currently activated information
subjective_experience.cognitive_load: Subjective effort required to maintain and process information
subjective_experience.capacity_limits: Experience of mental juggling when approaching limits
subjective_experience.interference_effects: Losing train of thought when distracted
subjective_experience.rehearsal_strategies: Internal repetition to maintain important information

individual_differences.capacity_variation: Working memory capacity correlates with general intelligence and academic achievement
individual_differences.domain_specificity: Individuals may have different capacities across verbal vs. visuospatial domains
individual_differences.training_effects: Limited evidence for transfer of working memory training to other cognitive domains
individual_differences.developmental_trajectory: Capacity increases through childhood, peaks in young adulthood, gradual decline with aging

learning_contexts.instructional_design: Breaking complex information into manageable chunks
learning_contexts.multimedia_learning: Balancing visual and verbal information to avoid overload
learning_contexts.reading_comprehension: Holding previous content while integrating new information

decision_making.option_comparison: Limited capacity constrains number of alternatives effectively considered
decision_making.cognitive_biases: Simplification strategies when working memory overloaded
decision_making.environmental_support: External aids compensating for capacity limitations

attention_disorders.ADHD: Working memory deficits contribute to difficulty maintaining focus
attention_disorders.cognitive_aging: Declining working memory affecting complex task performance

characteristics: General knowledge about world independent of personal experience
Organized conceptual and factual information
More resistant to deterioration than episodic memory

organizational_principles.description: Concepts represented as nodes interconnected by meaningful relationships

properties.explanation: Activation of one concept spreads to related concepts
properties.experiential_example: Thinking about 'dog' primes related concepts like 'cat', 'pet', 'bark'
properties.measurement: Semantic priming effects in reaction time experiments

properties.explanation: Concepts arranged in taxonomic levels from general to specific
properties.cognitive_efficiency: Properties inherited from higher levels without redundant storage

properties.explanation: Concepts defined by combinations of semantic features
properties.experiential_example: Bird: has wings, lays eggs, can fly (typically)
properties.cognitive_implications: Category judgments based on feature matching process

retrieval_phenomena.description: Faster recognition of typical category members
retrieval_phenomena.example: Robin verified as bird faster than penguin
retrieval_phenomena.explanation: Closer match to category prototype or more feature overlap

retrieval_phenomena.description: Verification time increases with conceptual distance
retrieval_phenomena.example: Longer verification for 'shark is an animal' than 'shark is a fish'
retrieval_phenomena.explanation: Longer network traversal or more comparison operations

organizational_principles.description: Organized knowledge structures about common situations and procedures

properties.experiential_example: Restaurant script: being seated, ordering, eating, paying
properties.cognitive_function: Enables prediction and appropriate behavior in familiar contexts

properties.explanation: Unspecified elements filled with typical values
properties.experiential_example: Assuming restaurant has menus without being explicitly told
properties.cognitive_efficiency: Reduces processing load by filling gaps with likely information

properties.explanation: Framework with variables that take specific values in instances
properties.experiential_example: Restaurant schema slots: type of restaurant, menu items, payment methods
properties.cognitive_function: Facilitates encoding new instances by focusing on unique elements

memory_effects.description: Better recall for schema-consistent than schema-irrelevant information
memory_effects.example: Remembering typical restaurant elements better than unusual background details

memory_effects.description: Confident memory for unstated but implied information
memory_effects.example: Remembering 'ordering food' in restaurant story when not explicitly mentioned
memory_effects.explanation: Schema activation automatically generates expected elements

memory_effects.example: Vividly remembering restaurant where payment occurs before eating
memory_effects.explanation: Unexpected information receives deeper processing and distinct encoding

explicit_learning.mechanisms: Intentional study, educational instruction, deliberate practice
explicit_learning.characteristics: Conscious awareness of learning, effort allocation, strategic encoding
explicit_learning.examples: Studying vocabulary, learning historical dates, memorizing procedures

implicit_learning.mechanisms: Repeated exposure, statistical learning, contextual association
implicit_learning.characteristics: Acquisition without conscious intent, gradual accumulation, difficulty articulating
implicit_learning.examples: Grammar rule abstraction, category prototype formation, cultural knowledge absorption

conceptual_development.childhood_progression: Perceptual to abstract categorization, increasing hierarchical organization
conceptual_development.expertise_development: Novice to expert transitions through knowledge restructuring and chunking
conceptual_development.neuroplasticity: Semantic network reorganization with learning and experience

retrieval_phenomena.description: Feeling of knowing with temporary retrieval failure
characteristics: Strong feeling of knowledge possession
Partial information access (first letter, syllable count)
Frustrating subjective experience
Often resolved after attention diversion
retrieval_phenomena.mechanisms: Successful semantic activation with blocked phonological retrieval
retrieval_phenomena.frequency_factors: Increases with age, fatigue, and low-frequency words

retrieval_phenomena.description: Retrieval slows as more facts associated with a concept
retrieval_phenomena.example: Slower verification of 'The lawyer is in the bank' when multiple lawyer locations learned
retrieval_phenomena.mechanism: Interference from competing associations during retrieval
retrieval_phenomena.real_world_implications: Information overload in learning, cue distinctiveness importance

retrieval_phenomena.description: Practicing some information impairs recall of related unpracticed information
retrieval_phenomena.mechanism: Inhibition of competing information during selective retrieval
retrieval_phenomena.educational_implications: Testing effect may have collateral damage on untested related material
